A school '''period''' is a block of time allocated for lessons, classes in schools.<ref name="Definition htof Class Period">{{cite web | url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/class+period | title=Definition of Class Period by The Free Dictionary | publisher=Farlex | accessdate=July 22, 2011}}</ref> They typically last between 40 and 60 minutes, with around 3-8 periods per school day. However, especially in higher education, there can be many more. Educators determine the number and length of these periods, and may even regulate how each period will be used. One common example of this practice is to designate at least one compulsory period a day for physical education.<ref name="Proposed Compulsory Sports Period">{{cite news | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Gill-wants-a-compulsory-sports-period-in-schools/articleshow/5854061.cms#ixzz0yHgn7YRb | title=The Times of India: Gill wants a compulsory sports period in schools | accessdate=July 22, 2011 | work=The Times Of India | date=April 25, 2010}}</ref>
==Free period== One special example of a [[high school]] period is the free period. These typically involve having 15 minutes of mostly unsupervised activities. A free period (also called "free" "spare" or "unstructured") is generally found in most high schools and [[college]]s. During a free period, a student can either: * Walk around the [[campus]] freely until the next period. Some high schools permit students to leave the campus and go home, visit shops or areas nearby that are outside the school grounds. * Stay in a designated [[common room|study room]] or [[classroom]] and either talk or work on [[homework]] * Use it as an opportunity to meet up with [[teacher]]s and ask about missed work or another question. * Study for any upcoming tests/exams. * In some schools, [[lunch]] is also consumed during a student's free period.
Some schools have an extended lunch period and that could be used as a free period as well. Lunch periods in high school could be up to 60 minutes long.
A free period in a [[college]] is a time period that a student is not enrolled in a class. During the free period, students are completely free of adult supervision and could do whatever they want that complies to the campus rules and the law.
==Study period== Another special example of a middle school and high school period is the study period. In school or college, a study period is a period in a student's timetable where a student may undertake self-directed learning activities, rather than having lessons being taught by a teacher.
While study periods are normally intended for study activities, such as set exercises, problem solving, or homework, students often consider these periods of the school day as free periods and may use the time to socialize rather than study. For this reason, study periods may often be supervised by a teacher being present in the study room. In some instances, the teacher may even tutor the students, and the study period may become a tutorial, although this is not normally the case. Study periods often occur because of scheduling conflicts in the school timetable, when there is a mismatch between available students, teachers, subjects and classrooms.
Study periods are generally monitored by teachers or teacher's aides, who often encourage students to use this time to complete homework, catch up on missing assignments, or study for tests or quizzes. Sometimes, students also use periods to converse, make phone calls, text message, play video games, or otherwise socialize or pursue non-academic topics, though this is sometimes discouraged or forbidden. Periods in which such things are allowed are occasionally differentiated from study periods by the name "free period". Some students even eat lunch during a study period due to long lines and short lunch periods at their schools.
Study periods are often used by students to visit with teachers, who have a "prep period", in order to discuss work or assignments. A study period can be a period to utilize school resources or otherwise request teacher assistance in any subject not understood by the student.
Many academics feel that study period is an inefficient allocation of time which is often underutilized, but others say it is a positive addition to a regular schedule because it creates a good environment for completing homework or large projects.

{{About||different styles|Shalwar kameez}} The Punjabi '''salwar''' is part of the Punjabi suit which is the traditional attire of the [[Punjab region]] of the [[Indian subcontinent]]. It is known for its lively hues, rich fabrics and embroidery. The suit features three items - a kameez (top), salwar (bottom) and dupatta (scarf). The women's Punjabi salwar suit style has become popular all over the sub-continent and beyond<ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2000/20000527/windows/main1.htm The Tribune Pran Nevile 27 May 2000]</ref><ref>Lois May Burger (1963) A Study of Change in Dress as Related to Social and Political Conditions in an Area of North India [https://books.google.com/books?id=CGFBAAAAYAAJ&dq=mughal+kameez+kurta&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+punjabi+lokh]</ref> reaching even the remote parts of [[Ladakh]].<ref>Textiles, Costumes, and Ornaments of the Western Himalaya by Omacanda Hāṇḍā [https://books.google.com/books?id=JFPnh9B5zncC&pg=PA278&lpg=PA278&dq=Textiles,+Costumes+and+Ornaments+of+the+Western+Himalyas+O+Handa&source=bl&ots=O8Y5jaDMu_&sig=wG-BjJ8_12ZPB0U2kHK2c5W8iSY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Kg13VN_hCrKd7ga3lYG4Cg&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBg#v=snippet&q=punjabi&f=false]</ref> It is also the national dress for [[Pakistan]],<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=OGd1VYycEMnuUNCQgZgO&id=PvoMAQAAIAAJ&dq=punjabi+salwar+kameez+is+national+dress+of+pakistan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=purely Basic facts about Pakistan, Issue 5 (1950)]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=l5Sb4e4cL7gC&pg=PA386&dq=pakistan+national+dress+punjabi+suit&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KryJVdqLDfSp7Aar_bqYBA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=pakistan%20national%20dress%20punjabi%20suit&f=false Nelson,Lise . Seager,Joni (2008) A Companion to Feminist Geography]</ref> since the later 1960s with the Punjabi salwar being used in government offices.<ref>Qadeer. Mohammad (2006) Pakistan - Social and Cultural Transformations in a Muslim Nation [https://books.google.com/books?id=ll02P7G5XD8C&pg=PA69&dq=sindh+shalwar++baloch&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Nx2NVfS5OoWuUYeig5AH&ved=0CFkQ6AEwBg#v=snippet&q=punjabi%20shalwar&f=false]</ref>
The outfit has been a part of Punjabi tradition for centuries whether as the suthan<ref>[http://revenueharyana.gov.in/html/gazeteers/karnal%20Gazeetter%201892.pdf 1892 Punjab Gazeetter] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140501200322/http://revenueharyana.gov.in/html/gazeteers/karnal%20Gazeetter%201892.pdf |date=2014-05-01 }}</ref><ref>Kumar, Raj (2008) Encyclopaedia of Untouchables Ancient, Medieval and Modern [https://books.google.com/books?id=e8o5HyC0-FUC&pg=PA51&dq=suthan+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6WGFVa_kOcm0UdvBgLAC&ved=0CB8Q6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=suthan%20punjab&f=false]</ref> kurta/kurti ensemble or the salwar jhaga (kameez)/kurta combination. The outfit includes the [[Patiala salwar]] and the [[Saraiki shalwar suits]] of the [[Punjab region]].
==Punjabi suit== The term Punjabi suit refers to the three piece ensemble comprising the head scarf, kameez and the salwar. However, the term also encompasses the older variety of the Punjabi suthan suit which is made up of the head scarf, kurta/kurti and Punjabi suthan.<ref name="autogenerated5">Sidhu Brard, Gurnam Singh (2007) East of Indus: My Memories of Old Punjab [https://books.google.com/books?id=UUdYFH9skIkC&pg=PA331&dq=punjab+sutthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=M4-aVaWkFceuU5zwmZAD&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=punjab%20sutthan&f=false]</ref>
===Punjabi suthan and kurta suit===
====Etymology==== The word suthan is derived from the [[Sanskrit]] word svasthana,<ref name="autogenerated2"/> which means tight fitting trousers which in turn is derived from the Central Asian word Samstamni.<ref name="autogenerated3">Archaeological Congress and Seminar Papers: Papers Presented at the 4th Annual Congress of the Indian Archaeological Society and the Seminars Held at Nagpur on the 10th, 11th, and 12th Nov. 1970, Volume 4, Part 1970 [https://books.google.com/books?id=_xJuAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+trousers&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nwSFVfuFBseOU76WqIgL&ved=0CFoQ6AEwCTgK]</ref><ref>Subbarayappa, B. V. Indo-Soviet Seminar on Scientific and Technological Exchanges Between India and Soviet Central Asia in Medieval Period, Bombay, November 7–12, 1981: Proceedings [https://books.google.com/books?id=IerQAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+trousers&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nwSFVfuFBseOU76WqIgL&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAjgK]</ref> The suthan are trousers cut straight and tight, as opposed to the salwar, which is baggy and can be full of folds.<ref>Edward O'Brien (of the Indian Civil Service ) (1881) Glossary of the Multani Language Compared with Punjábi and Sindhi [https://books.google.com/books?id=u10IAAAAQAAJ&q=multani+suthan&dq=multani+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gG-NVc3zNaHT7QbWq4CoBw&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA]</ref> The tight suthan is loose to the knees but the loose Punjabi suthan is loose to the lower legs and very tight at the ankles. The salwar ends in a band which is loose fitting. Despite this difference, people use the word suthan and salwar interchangeably to describe loose suthans and salwars,<ref>John, A (2009) Two dialects one region: A sociolinguistic approach to dialects as identity markers.</ref> with the loose suthan resembling the salwar.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=yCRuAAAAMAAJ&q=sutthan+punjab&dq=sutthan+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=64uaVYOKNMf4UuDPjng&ved=0CC8Q6AEwBDgK Dhavalikar, Madhukar Keshav (2003) Archaeology of western India]</ref>
Prior to the use of the term pajama, the term suthan was used. Therefore, the woollen pajamas of Gilgit<ref>Knight, E.F. (1996) Where Three Empires Meet: A Narrative of Recent Travel in Kashmir, Western Tibet, Gilgit, and the Adjoining Countries [https://books.google.com/books?id=3zl-b6g4GDIC&pg=PA277&dq=dardistan+++pyjamas&hl=en&sa=X&ei=a0uUVdTeFJajyASgrIaQAg&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=dardistan%20%20%20pyjamas&f=false]</ref> are also referred to as suthan.<ref>Kapur, Manohar Lal (1992) Social and economic history of Jammu and Kashmir State, 1885-1925 A.D. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3ecbAAAAIAAJ&q=gilgit+suthan&dq=gilgit+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jE6UVaXeM8ityASoj464CA&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA]</ref> However, these are not of the Punjabi variety. The churidar pajama was also referred to as the suthan.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ALpHAAAAYAAJ&q=churidar+pyjama+known+as+suthan&dq=churidar+pyjama+known+as+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=C0-UVa77A4P6yASey6vYCQ&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAQ Census of India, 1981: Himachal Pradesh. Series 7]</ref>
The word suthana was also used in [[Hindi]], to describe pajamas.<ref>The University (1982)Panjab University Research Bulletin: Arts, Volume 13, Issue 1 - Volume 14, Issue 1 [https://books.google.com/books?id=nvE7AQAAIAAJ&q=suthan+19th+century&dq=suthan+19th+century&hl=en&sa=X&ei=l_yEVY_FGIGoUrGIgZgN&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAg]</ref>
<gallery> File:GuptaDanceMusic02.jpg|Ancient svasthana and varbana outfit worn during [[Gupta Empire]], the basis of the Punjabi suthan suit </gallery>
====History==== [[File:20th (Punjab) Regiment of Bengal Native Infantry. Painting by Walter Fane (1828-85), 1868.jpg|thumb|20th (Punjab) Regiment of Bengal Native Infantry. Painting by Walter Fane (1828-85), 1868]]
=====Suthan===== The use of the suthan in the [[Punjab region]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=i73QAAAAMAAJ&q=lahore+suthan&dq=lahore+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=svmTVYvWEYv8UIKGgKgD&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBA W.H. Allen, 1925 The National Review, Volume 86]</ref> also called suthana in Punjabi is a survival of the ancient svasthana.<ref name="autogenerated3"/><ref>Catherine Ella Blanshard Asher, Thomas R. Metcalf (1994) Perceptions of South Asia's visual past [https://books.google.com/books?id=HDluAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+punjab&dq=svasthana+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HgqFVeXjMMPcUbysgvAE&ved=0CEsQ6AEwCA]</ref> Svasthana referred to a lower garment which can be described as a type of trousers. The svasthana was in use amongst the rulers in the [[Mauryan]] times(322–185 BCE).<ref>Vishnu, Asha (1993) Material Life of Northern India: Based on an Archaeological Study, 3rd Century B.C. to 1st Century B. [https://books.google.com/books?id=zaJ5oyrqBakC&pg=PA11&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lv2EVdnoNofrUqWKt9gH&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=svasthana%20trousers&f=false]</ref> Evidence of the use of svasthana amongst the ruling classes has also been observed in [[North India]] during the [[Kushan Empire]] between the 1st and 3rd centuries C.E.<ref>Archaeological Congress and Seminar Papers: Papers Presented at the 4th Annual Congress of the Indian Archaeological Society and the Seminars Held at Nagpur on the 10th, 11th, and 12th Nov. 1970, Volume 4, Part 1970 [https://books.google.com/books?ei=MraFVYSaF4KPU_i-gYAB&id=_xJuAAAAMAAJ&dq=kushana+svasthana&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+svasthana]</ref> It was noted in use during the [[Gupta Empire]] between 4th and 6th centuries C.E.<ref>Mohapatra, Ramesh Prasad (1992) Fashion Styles of Ancient India: A Study of Kalinga from Earliest Times to Sixteenth Century Ad [https://books.google.com/books?ei=smSFVdO6F8jzUvW3gOgP&id=QO2BAAAAMAAJ&dq=svasthana+harsha&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=svasthana+]</ref> and during King Harsha's<ref name="autogenerated3b">A.V. Narasimha Murthy, K.V. Ramesh (1987). ''Giridharaśrī: essays on Indology'': Dr. G.S. Dikshit felicitation volume [https://books.google.com/books?id=Q_-1AAAAIAAJ&q=svasthana+harsha&dq=svasthana+harsha&hl=en&sa=X&ei=smSFVdO6F8jzUvW3gOgP&ved=0CEYQ6AEwCQ]</ref> rule during the 7th century C.E.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=QCfjAAAAMAAJ&q=Harshacharita++svasthana&dq=Harshacharita++svasthana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Pf-bVfGzM8PqUtCvgKgL&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ Journal of the Uttar Pradesh Historical Society Journal, Volume 23, Parts 1-2 (1950)]</ref>
A version of the svasthana has been noted in [[ancient India]] which sticks to the calves with narrow circumferences of the lower opening.<ref>Bahl, Vinay (2005) What Went Wrong with "history from Below": Reinstating Human Agency as Human Creativity [https://books.google.com/books?id=9euGAAAAIAAJ&q=svasthana+trousers&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lv2EVdnoNofrUqWKt9gH&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBg]</ref> This is similar to the Punjabi ghuttana which is loose at the thighs and tightens at the knees and ends at the calves (with some versions ending at the knees and the lower legs being naked).<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=WCBuAAAAMAAJ&q=punjab+half+trousers&dq=punjab+half+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2i-RVbbwJoupsgHxkbuADQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAg Proceedings - Punjab History Conference (2001)]</ref> This suggests that the use of the suthan is indigenous to the [[Punjab region]]. Ultimately, however, the svasthana could have been introduced to [[ancient India]] from [[Central Asia]],<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=lv2EVdnoNofrUqWKt9gH&id=bOxZAAAAIAAJ&dq=svasthana+trousers&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=svasthana+ Indian Institute of Advanced Study Transactions, Volume 17]</ref> but its use became popular amongst the general people in the local area during the medieval period,<ref>Thapliyal, Uma Prasad (1978) Foreign elements in ancient Indian society, 2nd century BC to 7th century AD.[https://books.google.com/books?id=9X4BAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+trousers&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lv2EVdnoNofrUqWKt9gH&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBw]</ref> particularly, the 7th century C.E.<ref name="autogenerated3b"/> The wearing of the suthan and kurta continued to be prevalent during the [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] period between 1526-1748 C.E.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=RpKVVYmMBevB7Abys7HwBg&id=T_mC-s_K-6sC&dq=punjabi+suthan+ghagra&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=punjab Misra, Rekha (1967) Women in Mughal India, 1526-1748 A.D]</ref> and has been in use in unbroken succession since ancient times.<ref>Aniruddha Ray, Kuzhippalli Skaria Mathew (2002) Studies in history of the Deccan: medieval and modern : Professor A.R. Kulkarni felicitation volume [https://books.google.com/books?id=OT9uAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+punjab+unbroken&dq=svasthana+punjab+unbroken&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Yz6FVfLeB8W2UYG1gvgM&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAA]</ref> The National Review (1925) notes that the suthan was in much use in the Punjab, generally in white washable cloth but on feast days of rich material such as Lahore silk.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=p_ubVdX_IoLkUaa6v5gL&id=i73QAAAAMAAJ&dq=suthan+lahore&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=lahore W.H. (1925) The National Review, Volume 86]</ref> The svasthana was worn with the tunic called varbana<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=A1jrAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+tunic&dq=svasthana+tunic&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wWqFVeSIB4b0UpvsgqgB&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBg J. J. Bhabha (1969) Mārg̲, Volume 23 Marg Publications (1969)]</ref> which was tight fitting.
=====Kurta/Kurti===== [[File:Phulkari kurta.JPG|thumb|Phulkari kurta]] [[File:Women's Punjabi kurti.jpg|thumb|Women's Punjabi kurti]] [[File:Saraiki children wearing cloths & saraiki Fashion ofr children.JPG|thumb|left|Saraiki kurti]] The use of side slits in the straight cut Punjabi kurta can be traced to the 11th century C.E.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=irh9dvlLz3MC&pg=PA118&dq=kurtaka+dress&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1laGVZziN8yBUfWDgOAD&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=kurtaka%20dress&f=false Ghurye, Govind Sadashiv (1966) Indian Costume]</ref> female kurtaka worn in parts of north India and was a short shirt, with sleeves extending from the shoulders, to the middle of the body, and had slashes on the left and the right sides.<ref>Yadava,Ganga Prasad (1982) Dhanapāla and His Times: A Socio-cultural Study Based Upon His Works [https://books.google.com/books?id=aY_I3zgxfpsC&pg=PA107&dq=kurtaka+dress&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1laGVZziN8yBUfWDgOAD&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=kurtaka%20dress&f=false]</ref> This is the same as the modern straight cut kurta which has side slits and worn by women in Punjab.<ref>Sharma, Brij Narain (1966) Social life in Northern India, A.D. 600-1000</ref>
In modern usage, a short kurta is referred to as the kurti. However, traditionally, the kurti is a short cotton coat <ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=7SdGAQAAIAAJ&q=kurti+is+punjabi+dress&dq=kurti+is+punjabi+dress&hl=en&sa=X&ei=FRCHVY3YI4P-UM_GuvAD&ved=0CDIQ6AEwADgK Punjab District Gazetteers: Rawalpindi District (v. 28A) (1909)]</ref><ref>Compiled and published under the authority of the Punjab government, (1939)Punjab District and State Gazetteers: Part A].[https://books.google.com/books?id=6eY2AQAAMAAJ&q=punjab++kurti&dq=punjab++kurti&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6BWHVZL0Dou9UeetgOgP&ved=0CGEQ6AEwCQ]</ref>(without side slits) and is believed to have descended from the tunic of the Shunga period (2nd century B.C.).<ref>Panjab University Research Bulletin: Arts, Volume 13, Issue 1 - Volume 14, Issue (1982) [https://books.google.com/books?ei=PgKHVa7dK8arUazcgLgD&id=nvE7AQAAIAAJ&dq=kurtaka+punjabi+kurti&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=sunga]</ref> The local style of kurti also includes the type that flares out around the waist.<ref name="autogenerated6">[https://books.google.com/books?id=b8JFAQAAIAAJ&q=punjabi+kurti++anga&dq=punjabi+kurti++anga&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAGoVChMIsvHjzrnnxgIV6xfbCh1M9gnd Punjab District Gazetteers: Sirmur state, 1934]</ref>
The traditional Punjabi kurti is front opening and is buttoned. Traditionally, a chain of gold or silver called zanjiri is woven into the buttons.<ref>Kehal, Harkesh Singh (2011) Alop ho riha Punjabi virsa bhag dooja. Lokgeet Parkashan. {{ISBN|978-93-5017-532-3}}</ref> The use of the kurti by women has been noted during the 1600s<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6-jZAAAAMAAJ&dq=punjab+kurti&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+kurti Dr Daljit Singh (2004) Punjab Socio-Economic Condition (1501-1700 A.D.)]</ref><ref>Sanjeev Prasad Srivastava, R. P. Srivastava (2001) Studies in Panjab Sculpture [https://books.google.com/books?id=W0SIptlc5rQC&pg=PA6&dq=punjab+dress+central+asian&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBjgKahUKEwiRlfnF9uvGAhUGPBQKHc8nA6E#v=onepage&q=punjab%20dress%20central%20asian&f=false]</ref> to the present day. The kurti can be front opening from below the neck to the waist, or cover the back but leave the stomach exposed with some styles fastening at the back. A variation of the kurti, known as a [[Bandi (jacket)|bandi]], is sleeveless and is worn as a pullover with no side slits and front opening. A longer version of the bandi is known as a chemise which has a lace around its hem.<ref>Dr SIngh, Sadhu (2010) Punjabi boli di virasat. Chenta Prakashan. {{ISBN|817883618-1}}</ref> Both bandi and chemise traditionally have been worn by women indoors. Somer versions are worn as pullovers with no side slits and font opening. The [[choli]] is referred to as kurti in Punjabi which can be half or full sleeved and be hip<ref>Arabinda Biswas, India. Indian Costumes (1985) Ministry of Information and Broadcasting. Publications Division [https://books.google.com/books?id=vdyBAAAAMAAJ&q=ghagra+kurti+-choli+punjabi&dq=ghagra+kurti+-choli+punjabi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBGoVChMI4_7xsenwxgIVCsAUCh1GhwCS]</ref> length. {{clear}}
====Design==== Punjabi women in [[west Punjab]]<ref name="himalmag.com">[http://www.himalmag.com/component/content/article/1961-The-Salwar-Revolution.html] The Salwar Revolution Article</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=JihGAQAAIAAJ&q=ghagra+punjab&dq=ghagra+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nbtsVei0OqOf7gaFr4OgCw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAzgo Punjab District Gazetteers: Mianwali district (v. 30A) (1915)]</ref> and [[east Punjab]]<ref name="himalmag.com"/> (which includes [[Haryana]] and [[Himachal Pradesh]]) traditionally wore the Punjabi suthan suit which was made of a head scarf, upper garment and suthan.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=155wVdHvK4erU5WDgOgH&id=jGIBAAAAMAAJ&dq=punjabi+suthan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=suthan Sir Jadunath Sarkar (1958) Essays presented to Sir Jadunath Sarkar]</ref>
=====Types===== The Punjabi suthan is of two types: loose to above the ankles and tight at the ankles, or loose to the knees, and then cut straight and tight to the ankles.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=qR6LVbiwLJOp7AbF7YHYBw&id=NcRFAQAAIAAJ&dq=suthan+punjabi&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=shalwar Punjab District Gazetteers: pt. 1 Muzaffargarh district, 1929]</ref>
=====Loose Punjabi suthan===== It was noted by Alberuni in the 11th century C.E. that the local drawers are of gigantic proportions.<ref>Kumar, Raj (2008) Encyclopaedia of Untouchables Ancient, Medieval and Modern [https://books.google.com/books?id=e8o5HyC0-FUC&pg=PA239&dq=sindh+kurta+dress+medieval+times&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o9OKVYimMYjlUdWJhKgG&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=sindh%20kurta%20dress%20medieval%20times&f=false]</ref> This could point to the loose Punjabi suthan which, unlike the Punjabi salwar, has multiple pleats and is very baggy with many folds. The suthan can also be arranged in plaits.<ref>Wace, E.G. (1874) Report on the land revenue settlement of the Hazara District of the Punjab : 1868 - 1874 [https://books.google.com/books?ei=UPeUVeT9MMi9UbX_i4AJ&id=bMPTuskHAqUC&dq=hazara+kurta&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=ending+above]</ref> Up to 20 yards of cloth can be used which hangs in innumerable folds.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=s-Y2AQAAMAAJ&q=punjab++suthan&dq=punjab++suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cYFnVarhJ8mS7AaE6oPYCQ&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAQ Punjab District Gazetteers (1932)]</ref> Some varieties, such as those of [[Chakwal]], can use between 30 and 40 yards of cloth which are made with overhanging pleats.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=eOtAAQAAMAAJ&q=sutthan+punjabi&dq=sutthan+punjabi&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4eSaVY_JLsSP7Aa15byAAw&ved=0CEkQ6AEwCQ Punjab District Gazetteers 1907 Jhelum District ..]</ref>
The material used for the suthan is traditionally coloured cotton with silk lines going down and is called sussi.<ref>Punjab District Gazetteer: Reprint of Ludhiana District and Malerkotla State Gazetteer, 1904 [https://books.google.com/books?id=E-c2AQAAMAAJ&q=punjabi+suthan&dq=punjabi+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=aXJsVfeSEsqM7Aa06IGQCA&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBzgK]</ref> Sussi was manufactured in various places such as [[Hoshiarpur]], [[Amritsar]], [[Multan]] and [[Jhang]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=dXoiAAAAMAAJ&q=jhang+district+salwar&dq=jhang+district+salwar&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Vf2LVcbUKsPqUrfngdAO&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg Gauba, Anand (1988) Amritsar, a study in urban history, 1840-1947]</ref>
Instead of the Punjabi salwar paunchay at the bottom of the salwar, which are loose,<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960">Mohinder Singh Randhawa. (1960) Punjab: Itihas, Kala, Sahit, te Sabiachar aad.Bhasha Vibhag, Punjab, Patiala.</ref> the Punjabi suthan is gathered midway between the knees and the ankles to fit closely to the leg and end in a tight band at the ankles which is what distinguishes the two lower garments.<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960"/> The tight band of the suthan is a remnant of the ancient svasthana trousers which were tight fitting to the thighs. The use of loose material is a local development. The pleats of the suthan either gather in circles resembling bangles, or fall vertically to the ankles. As the distinction between the loose Punjabi suthan and the baggy salwar rests on the ankle band, some view the loose Punjabi suthan as another version of the salwar,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6-jZAAAAMAAJ&q=punjabi+suthan&dq=punjabi+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=P96LVfe6AsGqUZGIgvgM&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBQ Singh, Daljit (2004) Punjab Socio-Economic Condition (1501-1700 A.D.)]</ref> with the definition of suthan being reserved for the tight Punjabi suthan. The loose suthan is primarily a female costume, but in some areas, such as [[Rawalpindi]], was worn by men too,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Vu5BAQAAMAAJ&q=men+punjab+suthan&dq=men+punjab+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lBqPVePgI4uv7Ab66574DA&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAw Punjab District Gazetteers, Volume 28, Part 1 Rawalpindi. (1909)]</ref> which is also called tambi when worn by men.<ref>Bailey, Thomas Grahame (1919) An English-Panjabi Dictionary: Romanized [https://books.google.com/books?id=LOxpU2Kh7uEC&pg=PA126&dq=sutthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ppKaVZDRC4PuUM_XlNAK&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=sutthan&f=false]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Wf5tAAAAMAAJ&q=tambi+suthan&dq=tambi+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V-maVYW9A4Xd7Qa5gZ_oAg&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAQ Gazetteer of the Rawalpindi District, 1893-94]</ref> The loose suthan was also worn by men in [[Bannu]] ([[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]])<ref>[http://www.khyber.org/publications/031-035/sociallifebannu.shtml#Clothing Khyber.Org]</ref> which has historical and cultural connections with the rest of the [[Punjab region]].<ref>Social & Religious Life in Bannu Excerpts from Gazetteer of the Bannu District, 1887 (present day Khyber Pakhtunkwa, Pakistan formerly of British Punjab Province) [http://www.khyber.org/publications/031-035/sociallifebannu.shtml]</ref><ref>Pakistan Studies Centre, University of Sind, 2005 -Grassroots, Volume 33 [https://books.google.com/books?id=8_dtAAAAMAAJ&q=hazara+punjabi++n+w+f+p&dq=hazara+punjabi++n+w+f+p&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6h6VVfaiFcmVUZXqmbgE&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBw]</ref> <gallery> File:Pahari women kashmir3.jpg|Women in Punjabi suthan 1890 File:Nihang Singh and Nihang Singhani.jpg|19th Century Punjabi suthan suit worn by the lady on the right File:Punjabi Sikh woman in Amritsar Punjabi suthan and short kurta 1874.jpg|Punjabi woman in Punjabi suthan and short kurta 1874 File:Market Place, Bikanir 1896. Woman on left in loose Punjabi suthan suit.jpg|Woman on right in loose Punjabi suthan suit File:Men in British Punjab army in tight and loose Punjabi suthans 1895.jpg|Men in British Punjab army in tight and loose Punjabi suthans 1895 File:A Punjabi woman in Kurti and suthan visiting the Attar, the pharmacist. 1852.jpg|A Punjabi woman in Kurti and suthan visiting the Attar, the pharmacist. 1852 </gallery>
=====Tight Punjabi suthan===== The tight Punjabi suthan is a variation of the ancient svasthana, and was still popular in the [[Punjab region]] in the 19th century. The tight suthan is baggy from the knees up<ref>Baden Henry Baden-Powell 1872) Hand-book of the Manufactures & Arts of the Punjab: With a Combined Glossary & Index of Vernacular Trades & Technical Terms ... Forming Vol. Ii to the "Hand-book of the Economic Products of the Punjab" Prepared Under the Orders of Government page 115 the tight suthan was also worn in Bannu which is now in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan, formerly of British Punjab Province [https://books.google.com/books?id=gg_JAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA116&dq=punjabi+clothing+in+bannu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=g7mTVdpMwfdSxqCZ-Ag&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=they%20fit%20tight&f=false]</ref> and tight from the knees down to the ankles<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1s5AAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=letters+from+india+and+kashmir&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ODODVeXaAYSTsAHpi5-4Bg&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=letters%20from%20india%20and%20kashmir&f=false Letters from India and Kashmir (1874)]</ref> (a remnant of the tight fit ancient svasthana). The tight suthan remained popular in the [[Punjab, India|East Punjab]] into the 1960s.<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960"/> In [[Multan]], the tight suthan remained popular till the early 21st century.<ref>Chaudhry, Nazir Ahmad (2002) Multan Glimpses: With an Account of Siege and Surrender [https://books.google.com/books?ei=FCyOVe73Noy27gbFnongBg&id=_fxtAAAAMAAJ&dq=over+time+baloch+stopped+wearing+shalwar+of+their+ancestors&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=ancestors]</ref> The Punjabi suthan is part of male and female attire and is part of traditional dress in the hills of [[Punjab, Pakistan]], including [[Bannu]]. It is still a traditional garment in [[Jammu Division|Jammu]] where it is held in high regard.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=hmSQVdiABaW17gapmr2QCg&id=gs27AAAAIAAJ&dq=tight+Dogri+pyjamas&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=tight+ Raina, A.D. (1968) Field study in Jammu and Kashmir]</ref> The Gaddi<ref name="autogenerated4"/> community wear the garment, especially in [[Pathankot]]<ref>Shashi, Shyam Singh (1977) The Gaddi Tribe of Himachal Pradesh: A Sociological Study [https://books.google.com/books?id=XZk9AAAAMAAJ&q=gaddi++pathankot&dq=gaddi++pathankot&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cjyVVcz3N4HdUOvptZAE&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA]</ref> and Nurpur ([[Gurdaspur District]]).Its variation known as the churidar suthan is worn in the Punjab mountainous region<ref>GORE, Frederick St. John. (1895) Lights & Shades of Hill Life in the Afghan and Hindu Highlands of the Punjab. A contrast ... With maps and illustrations, etc [http://access.bl.uk/item/pdf/lsidyv39189ee9]</ref> especially by the Gujjar community in the foothills of [[Punjab, India]],<ref name="autogenerated4">Hāṇḍā, Omacanda (1998) Textiles, Costumes, and Ornaments of the Western Himalaya. [https://books.google.com/books?id=JFPnh9B5zncC&dq=suthan+chamba&source=gbs_navlinks_s]</ref><ref>Sharma, V. P. Kohler-Rollefson, Ilse Pastoralism. Morton, John in India: A scoping study</ref> and [[Himachal Pradesh]]<ref>Kumar Suresh Singh, B. R. Sharma, Anthropological Survey of India, A. R. Sankhyan (1996) Himachal Pradesh [https://books.google.com/books?id=XEduAAAAMAAJ&q=suthan+himachal+pradesh&dq=suthan+himachal+pradesh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_zSDVZuyMYqmsgHdmaPYAQ&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAQ]</ref> whereby the upper part is loose but below the knees, the tight part is sewn in folds to create a bangles look. When worn in [[Jammu Division|Jammu]], the suthan is referred to as Dogri pants<ref>[http://www.planyourwedding.co.in/hyderabad/fashion/the-rockstar-dhoti.aspx Banerjee, Sanhati. The Rockstar Dhoti (15.01.2012)]</ref> or Dogri suthan. This is the basis of the [[churidar]] pyjama, which in the [[Punjab region]] is also known as the (full length) ghuttana<ref>Abdul Halim Sharar, Rosie Llewellyn-Jones, Veena Talwar Oldenburg (2001) The Lucknow Omnibus [https://books.google.com/books?ei=J6SVVe6lD4Gv7AaZtJmoAw&id=P1swAQAAIAAJ&dq=persian+churidar+pyjama&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=sikhs]</ref> which was adopted in [[Lucknow]] during the 19th century. Where the churidar suthan is tight up to the knees and wide above, the churidar pajama is tight below the calves and slightly loose above.<ref>Hankin, Nigel B. (1994) Hanklyn-Janklin, or, A stranger's rumble-tumble guide to some words, customs and quiddities Indian and Indo-British [https://books.google.com/books?id=rEZeAAAAIAAJ&q=persian+churidar+pyjama&dq=persian+churidar+pyjama&hl=en&sa=X&ei=J6SVVe6lD4Gv7AaZtJmoAw&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAzgK]</ref> The waist fits closer than the suthan.
In the late 19th century, the slim line riding breeches known as [[Jodhpurs|Jodhpuri]],<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=2ZF5EIfX9VwC&pg=PA56&dq=jodhpur+breeches+origins&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OFqRVZTUFMHkUvGCsbgH&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=jodhpur%20breeches%20origins&f=false Singh, Jaisal (2007) Polo in India]</ref> were developed along the lines of the tight fitting Punjabi suthan, albeit the [[churidar]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=vdyBAAAAMAAJ&q=jodhpurs+churidar&dq=jodhpurs+churidar&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XpuRVbL-L4qy7QbyhaqYAQ&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBQ Biswas, Arabinda (1985) Indian Costumes]</ref> is cited as an inspiration.<ref>Albert, Jack (2011)It's a Wonderful Word: The Real Origins of Our Favourite Words [https://books.google.com/books?id=CcsCBrxNXZQC&pg=PT72&dq=jodhpur+breeches+origins&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lY2RVd35PJCw7AaCyrPADw&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=jodhpur%20breeches%20origins&f=false]</ref>
Since the creation of [[India]] and [[Pakistan]], women of the [[Meo (ethnic group)|meo]] community of [[Rajasthan]] have adopted the salwar called khusni which, like the Punjabi suthan, is tight below the knees and loose above and is worn with a long kameez.<ref>Partap Chand Aggarwal (1971) Caste, religion, and power: an Indian case study [https://books.google.com/books?id=xBguAAAAMAAJ&dq=khusni+meos&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=khusni+]</ref> <gallery> File:Cheetah and keeper Jeypore. Man in tight Punjabi suthan. 1896.jpg|Man in tight Punjabi suthan. 1896 File:Sepoys of 20th Punjab Infantry and Hunza Gun. 1893. Men in Punjabi tight from knees suthan.jpg|1893. Men in Punjabi tight from knees suthan File:Men of the British Punjab army in suthans 1895 Punjab Hills. Churidar suthan.jpg|Men of the British Punjab army in Punjabi churidar suthans 1895 Punjab Hills File:Punjab Hills 1895. Kulu woman in churidar suthan. Himachal Pradesh.jpg|Punjab Hills 1895. Kulu woman in Punjabi churidar suthan. Himachal Pradesh. File:Bharatpore maharajah.jpg|he Nawab Muhammad Bahawal Khan Abbasi V Bahadur (1883–1907) of Bahawalpur State in suthan File:Nawab of Bahawalpur.JPG|Nawab of Bahawalpur and generals in suthan </gallery>
=====Upper garments===== Punjabi women wore the suthan with a kurta, kurti, kameez<ref>Sir [[Jadunath Sarkar]], Hari Ram Gupta (1958) Sir Jadunath Sarkar Commemoration Volumes: Essays presented to Sir Jadunath Sarkar [https://books.google.com/books?ei=DIaPVdunNqGU7Aag2IaACw&id=Sr85AQAAIAAJ&dq=punjabi+suthan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+suthan]</ref> or jhaga. The kurti could be straight cut ending at the waist or be a mini version of the anga,<ref name="autogenerated6"/> which ia a gown flowing to below the knees and even to the ankles (akin to the [[Anarkali Salwar Suit|anarkali]]) also known as an angarkha<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Vf4InPH0STQC&q=peshwaj+known+as+anga&dq=peshwaj+known+as+anga&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I_xzVc64AoblUoiPgLAB&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAA Rajaram Narayan Saletore (1974) Sex Life Under Indian Rulers]</ref><ref>Panjab University Research Bulletin: Arts, Volume 13, Issue 1 - Volume 14, Issue 1 (1982) [https://books.google.com/books?id=nvE7AQAAIAAJ&q=peshwaj+known+as+anga&dq=peshwaj+known+as+anga&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I_xzVc64AoblUoiPgLAB&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAg]</ref> and peshwaj<ref>B. N. Goswamy, Kalyan Krishna, Tarla P. Dundh (1993) Indian Costumes in the Collection of the Calico Museum of Textiles, Volume 5 [https://books.google.com/books?id=1IHWAAAAMAAJ&q=west+india+peshwaj+is+known+as+anga&dq=west+india+peshwaj+is+known+as+anga&hl=en&sa=X&ei=7AB0VfemDMKnU_u0gMgG&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAQ]</ref> which is similar to a loose coat and wadded with cotton.<ref>Punjab District Gazetteers - District Attock Year Published 1930 BK-000211-0160 [https://books.google.com/books?ei=CwV0VZfnNMnbU8OzguAC&id=3MNFAQAAIAAJ&dq=Punjab+District+Gazetteers+-+District+Attock+Year+anga&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+anga]</ref>
=====Variations===== Sometimes women replaced the suthan with a churidar pajamma, (a tradition noted by Baden-Powell in 1872 in his book Hand-book of the Manufactures and Arts of the Punjab)<ref>Baden-Powell, Baden. Henry (1872) Hand-book of the Manufactures and Arts of the Punjab [https://books.google.com/books?id=HnAIAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA105&dq=kurta+punjab+new&hl=en&sa=X&ei=m0VwVeLWLsv1ULWMgPgO&ved=0CEYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=kurta%20punjab%20new&f=false]</ref> which would then be covered with a [[Punjabi Ghagra]] when going outdoors. The [[Punjabi ghagra]] has its origins in the candataka which continued as a popular female dress in the seventh century.<ref>Uma Prasad Thapliyal (1978) Foreign elements in ancient Indian society, 2nd century BC to 7th century AD [https://books.google.com/books?id=9X4BAAAAMAAJ&q=candataka+dress&dq=candataka+dress&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MGqGVbOqNoGyU_HYgfAM&ved=0CFoQ6AEwCQ]</ref> The use of the svasthana was also popular in this period. However, the candataka ended at the thighs and the svasthana may have been used to cover the lower legs thus giving rise to the tradition of wearing the ghagra and the suthan together.
Older Punjabi women wore churidar pajamma and long kurta. These different styles were popular during the 1960s in [[Punjab, India|East Punjab]].<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960">Mohinder Singh Randhawa. (1960) Punjab: Itihas, Kala, Sahit, te Sabiachar aad.Bhasha Vibhag, Punjab, Patiala.</ref>
Certain members of the Punjabi community however, were wearing the suthan and kurti on its own without the [[Punjabi Ghagra]], a tradition documented in the Gazetter of Hoshiarpur District 1883-84<ref>Gazetteer of the Hoshiarpur District: 1883-84. Sang-e-Meel Publications, 2001.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=kPuHVZKVNIHaUbXipJgO&id=eIpuAAAAMAAJ&dq=punjab+ghagra+suthan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+suthan]</ref> and also in the 1915 Hissar Gazetteer<ref name="revenueharyana.gov.in">http://revenueharyana.gov.in/html/gazeteers/hissar%201915.pdf</ref> Punjabi women (and men) also wore the ghutanna, a type of pajamma which was shorter than the full length pajamma, and was tight and ended at the calf.<ref name="books.google.co.uk">Paintings and lifestyles of Jammu Region: 17th to 19th Century A.D Raj Kumar [https://books.google.com/books?id=f-1XyQ2eIG8C&pg=PA145&lpg=PA145&dq=punjabi+suthan+kameez&source=bl&ots=8nBGZ6-YoE&sig=ogpJUiErn2LLs9ReDFnx_NXnW-I&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lbR0VM74KMWE7gbA3IDwBA&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=punjabi%20suthan%20kameez&f=false]</ref>
Although the use of the Suthan subsequently spread to the [[Jammu Division|Jammu]] area of the [[Punjab region]],<ref name="books.google.co.uk"/> [[Sindh]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=PGBxVeXsAsvkUpzTgsgF&id=ql87AAAAMAAJ&dq=sindhi+never+wore++suthan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=paro S. P. Chablānī Economic conditions in Sind, 1592 to 1843 (1951)]</ref> (where it was not traditionally worn) and [[Kashmir]], in the plains of the [[Punjab region]], the suthan was replaced with the Punjabi version of the salwar and the Punjabi kameez which gained more and more popularity during the 1960s.<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960"/>
====Punjabi suthan suit revival==== In recent years, the Punjabi suthan suit has been revived. However, the pleats fall in a variet of ways and the ankle band is not as tight as the traditional Punjabi suthan.
===Punjabi salwar suit=== [[File:Saraiki Tehreek.JPG|thumb|Saraiki region of Punjab, Pakistan]]
====Punjabi salwar==== In its strictest sense, the salwar is baggy and loose straight down the legs, and gathered loosely at the ankles. During the medieval period, people adopted the Iraqi style of salwar in [[Multan]] and neighbouring [[Sindh]].<ref name="autogenerated1">Kumar, Raj (2008) Encyclopaedia of Untouchables Ancient, Medieval and Modern [https://books.google.com/books?id=e8o5HyC0-FUC&pg=PA239&dq=sindh+kurta+dress+medieval+times&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o9OKVYimMYjlUdWJhKgG&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=sindh%20kurta%20dress%20medieval%20times&f=false]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6xMNAAAAIAAJ&q=salwar+iraq+sindh+makran&dq=salwar+iraq+sindh+makran&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Th6OVe6fMdDY7AbjvoTgAQ&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ Said,Hakim Mohammad (1990) Road to Pakistan. 1. 712 - 1858]</ref> This type of salwar is traditionally very baggy and gathered at the ankles. It is still worn by the Kurdish community in [[Iraq]]. The presence of the baggy salwar was noted by Alberuni in the 11th century A.D.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> and continued to be envogue between the 16th and 18th centuries C.E. in [[Multan]]<ref>Dasti, Humaira Faiz (1998) Multan, a province of the Mughal Empire, 1525-1751 [https://books.google.com/books?ei=RLWLVf_yBMmjU7D4g5gH&id=kH3jAAAAMAAJ&dq=multan+shalwar&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+shalwar]</ref>
The Multani salwar is similar to the loose Punjabi suthan. Therefore, the distinction between the loose Punjabi suthan and the loose Multani salwar is fine and centres on the tight ankle band in the suthan, and on the suthan beginning to fit closer to the legs below the knees.
The original Punjabi loose salwar was not as baggy as the Multani style but was wide, with the gathering at the ankles being wide enough to cover the feet. Originally, up to ten yards of cloth was used to make Punjabi salwars.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=UdP_sSKIxf0C&pg=PA243&dq=salwar+punjab++afghan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nsSLVaeaOMnvUtvpuOgF&ved=0CFgQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=salwar%20punjab%20%20afghan&f=false Yarwood, Doreen (2011) Illustrated Encyclopedia of World Costume]</ref> The original Punjabi salwar was also not as baggy as other forms of the salwar, such as the type worn in [[Afghanistan]] ([[Khet partug|partug]])), the Balochi salwar,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=NUyOVZPdHMGd7AbqkoPYDw&id=P8JFAQAAIAAJ&dq=bahawalpur+shalwar&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=discarded Punjab district gazetteers, Volume 7, Part 1 (1923)]</ref> or the loose Punjabi suthan, and gathers more quickly below the knees and ends in a tight band. Eventually the modern Punjabi salwar came into being which is slim fitting and does not have wide ends as before.
Another style of salwar is the Pothohari salwar of the [[Pothohar]] area of the [[Punjab region]].<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960"/> The Pothohari salwar retains the wideness of the Punjabi suthan. The kameez is also wide. The chunni is a remnant of the large [[Chador|chadar]] popular in [[Punjab, Pakistan|West Punjab]] known as salari<ref>Kehal, Harkesh Singh (2011) Alop ho riha Punjabi virsa Lokgeet Parkashan {{ISBN|978-93-5017-532-3}}</ref> and the large [[Phulkari]] worn in various areas of the [[Punjab region]]. However, the Pothohari salwar suit did not attain universal acceptance. The Bahawalpuri salwar is also wide and baggy<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=28RCAQAAMAAJ&dq=bahawalpur+wide+trouser&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=wide+trousers Current Opinion, Volume 25 (1899)]</ref> with many folds. The material traditionally used for the Bahawalpuri shalwar and suthan is known as Sufi which is a mixture of cotton warp mixed with silk weft and gold threads running down the material.<ref>Extracts from the District & States Gazetteers of the Punjab, Pakistan, Volume 2 (1976) [https://books.google.com/books?id=2RluAAAAMAAJ&dq=bahawalpur+suththan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=sufi]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=wgEwAQAAIAAJ&q=bahawalpur+shalwar&dq=bahawalpur+shalwar&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ok2OVbvYLsqy7Qai6rKoDQ&ved=0CEMQ6AEwAw The Pakistan gazetteer, Volume 5 (2000)]</ref> <gallery> File:Nawab Muhammad Of Bawalpur 1868-1900.JPG|Nawab Muhammad Of Bahawalpur (1868-1900) wearing a loose Bahawalpuri salwar File:Prince Suba Sadiq Abbasi.JPG|Prince Suba Sadiq Abbasi, Bahawalpur </gallery>
====Punjabi kameez==== The Punjabi kameez is also cut straight with side slits.<ref>Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association, Volume 138 (1961) [https://books.google.com/books?id=tusHAQAAIAAJ&q=punjabi+churidar+pajama&dq=punjabi+churidar+pajama&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qPF1VaCZMMfXUdbqg5AO&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBzgK]</ref> This combination makes up the Punjab salwar suit outfit,<ref name="himalmag.com"/><ref name="ReferenceA">Alop Ho Reha Punjabi Virsa Harkesh Singh Kehal</ref> which is very popular,<ref name="himalmag.com"/><ref>[http://www.hindu.com/mag/2004/10/24/stories/2004102400380300.htm The Hindu: article RAMACHANDRA GUHA]</ref> and was developed in the [[Punjab region]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=h9-BAAAAMAAJ&q=mens+punjabi+kurta+straight&dq=mens+punjabi+kurta+straight&hl=en&sa=X&ei=91t1VebDLoLXUZK_gagL&ved=0CDIQ6AEwADgU Bhushan, Jamila Brij (1958) The Costumes and Textiles of India]</ref> The [[Punjabi ghagra]] is now rarely worn.
Before the development of the Punjabi salwar suit, the traditional dress of women of [[Punjab]] was the [[Punjabi Ghagra]], Punjabi suthan<ref name="revenueharyana.gov.in"/> and choli/kurti/kameez.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>Glossary of the Tribes and Castes of the Punjab and North East Volume 1 Ibbeston, Maclagan</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=GyoGPpPN_E0C&q=suthanr+punjab&dq=suthanr+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBWoVChMIhpGMk-OyxwIVybIUCh3yPQ64 Publication, Issue 111 1965]</ref><ref>Khan, Niaz Mohammad (1963) An economic survey of Abbaspur (Chak no. 2/10-L): a village in the Montgomery District [https://books.google.com/books?id=GCPRAAAAMAAJ&q=suthanr+punjab&dq=suthanr+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwBGoVChMIhpGMk-OyxwIVybIUCh3yPQ64]</ref>
=====Female dress: Punjabi salwar suit===== The [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] salwar Suit is worn in the Punjab in [[India]] and [[Pakistan]]. It consists of the chunni (head scarf), jhagga(kameez) and the salwar when worn by women. The chunni can be of varying lengths. The jhagga (kameez) is made up of two rectangular pieces sewn together with side slits, similar to a [[tunic]]. A kurta is also worn.
The salwar is similar to pajamas or pants, wide at the top and tightened loosely around the ankles with hard material, called paunchay. In the Punjab, the salwar kameez is also known as the chunni jhagga salwar suit. <gallery> File:MissPooja2.jpg|Punjabi suit File:Garba - graceful flow of colours.jpg|Girls in Punjabi suits File:Women of Puducherry.jpg|Women in Punjabi suits File:Rohi's Women Dress.JPG|Rohi (Cholistan) woman's bandhani dress (Punjab, Pakistan) File:Dance, Attari-Wagah, Punjab (10691014775).jpg|Dance, Attari-Wagah, women wearing Punjabi suits </gallery>
=====Male Dress: Punjabi salwar suit===== In some parts of the [[Punjab region]], especially the urban areas of [[Punjab, Pakistan]],<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=GQTABKAGaVgC&pg=PA119&dq=kurta+new+style+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WkxwVfbTD4bSU4Dag5AG&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q=chaadar&f=false Malik, Iftikhar Haider (2006) Culture and Customs of Pakistan]</ref> males wear the men's Punjabi suit. The upper garment is made of the straight cut kurta/kameez and the salwar resembles a slim fit pajama. In the past, the suthan was also commonly worn by men,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=OeU2AQAAMAAJ&q=punjabi++suthan&dq=punjabi++suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBjgUahUKEwjy8_zEnpHGAhVL7xQKHWUlAPo Punjab District and State Gazetteers: Part A (1911)]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=R6EIAAAAQAAJ&q=suthan+punjabi&dq=suthan+punjabi&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6yCLVaukCKqU7QbXgbG4Ag&ved=0CDAQ6AEwBDge Land revenue settlement reports 1876]</ref> a trend which can still be seen in some parts of the region (especially [[Jammu]] and [[Himachal Pradesh]]). <gallery> File:Shalvaar qamiz.JPG|Men's Punjabi salwar suit File:Punjabi kurta Ferozepur 1845.jpg|Punjabi kurta Ferozepur 1845 </gallery>
===Early history===
====Salwar==== Salwar is the generic term used to describe the lower garment developed in different regions. The earliest form of the salwar originated in [[Central Asia]] and its use was spread to [[Afghanistan]], [[India]], [[Iran]], the [[Arab]] world, [[Turkey]] and wherever the [[Turkic peoples|Turks]] established their empires.<ref>Jirousek, Charlotte. “Islamic Clothing.” In Encyclopedia of Islam. New York: Macmillan Pub. 2005.</ref> The [[Ottomans]] spread the use of the salwar throughout its empire.<ref>Annette Lynch, Mitchell D. Strauss (2014) Ethnic Dress in the United States: A Cultural Encyclopedia [https://books.google.com/books?id=tiEvBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA142&dq=chalvar&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwBTgeahUKEwjDubCPyOzGAhXIsxQKHR20Dt4#v=onepage&q=chalvar&f=false]</ref>
The use of the salwar in the [[Punjab region]] has been the result of influences from the Middle East, Central Asian Turks<ref>Martin, Richard C. (2004) Encyclopedia of Islam and the Muslim World: A-L, Volume 1 [https://books.google.com/books?id=OVcUAQAAIAAJ&q=sirwal+central+asia&dq=sirwal+central+asia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QCCgVeuuCsTB7ga635_gBg&ved=0CB8Q6AEwADgK]</ref> and finally, the Afghans.
In India, the term salwar includes the [[Sindhi dress|Sindhi suthan]], [[Punjab]]i suthan,<ref>Dr Singh, Daljit (2004) Punjab Socio-Economic Condition (1501-1700 A.D.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=6-jZAAAAMAAJ&q=punjab+kurta+suthan&dq=punjab+kurta+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pn1nVaGAGLOM7AaB8YOQBQ&ved=0CF4Q6AEwCA]</ref> [[Jammu dress|Dogri pajamma]] and the [[churidar]]. The term salwar kameez also includes the Kashmiri [[Phiran|Phiran/suthan outfit]].
In the [[Punjab region]], the salwar was made using a large amount of material but had no pleats or folds. The large salwar eventually gave rise to the Punjabi salwar.<ref name="autogenerated2">Paintings and Lifestyles of Jammu Region: From 17th to 19th Century A.D Raj Kumar [https://books.google.com/books?id=f-1XyQ2eIG8C&pg=PA352&lpg=PA352&dq=Paintings+and+Lifestyles+of+Jammu+Region:+From+17th+to+19th+Century+A.D.&source=bl&ots=8nBHQb20ox&sig=hehEhqbYaQ_NVTmqKdoksvPYpcY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xQt3VPu1Ms6V7AbByYHwBQ&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=punjab&f=false]</ref>
====Jhagga (kameez)==== In Turkic Central Asian culture, the salwar is accompanied by a tunic, forming the upper garment.<ref>Aryan, K.C (1983) The Cultural Heritage of Punjab, 3000 B.C. to 1947 A.D. [https://books.google.com/books?id=hCtuAAAAMAAJ&q=multan++salwar&dq=multan++salwar&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBjgKahUKEwiI-7Ss1pHGAhVJsxQKHbL5AE8]</ref> In the [[Punjab region]], the upper garment is the jhagga (kameez). The [[Ghaznavid]] Turks popularised the salwar/tunic attire in Afghanistan and Northern India,<ref>Jirousek, Charlotte. “Islamic Clothing.” In Encyclopedia of Islam. New York: Macmillan Pub. (2004)[http://char.txa.cornell.edu/islamicclothes.htm]</ref><ref>Flood, Finbarr Barry (2009) Objects of Translation: Material Culture and Medieval "Hindu-Muslim" Encounter [https://books.google.com/books?id=OLNE_li8C10C&pg=PA64&dq=kurta+sind+iraq&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qwCLVZ7COeHd7gawvoNo&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBg#v=snippet&q=trousers&f=false]</ref> especially in the [[Punjab region]].
==Other areas== The use of the suthan or the salwar has been adopted in other areas. People in [[Jammu]] have changed the traditional attire from the peshwaj (flowing to the ankles) <ref>Textiles, Costumes and Ornaments of the Western Himalayas O Handa</ref> to the kurta and Dogri suthan. In addition to the traditional lengha choli, women in [[Sindh]] wear the cholo (kameez) and suthan.<ref>I am a Sindhi: The Glorious Sindhi Heritage and Culture and Folklore of Sindh J P Vaswami</ref><ref>Sindh and The Races That Inhabit the Valley of the Indus Richard F Burton</ref> The Punjabi salwar suit is also worn by many people. The [[Phiran]] in [[Kashmir]]<ref>Paintings and lifestyles of Jammu Region: 17th to 19th Century A.D Raj Kumar</ref> traditionally flowed to the ankles, is now of varying lengths and is worn with a loose suthan. [[Kashyap Bandhu]] is regarded as the person responsible for spreading the use of the suthan with the phiran amongst the communities that resisted to adopt its use, eventually leading to the use of the salwar.<ref>Cultural Heritage of India- Kashmiri Pandit Contribution. The Publication of Kashmir Sabha, Calcutta (1999-2000) [http://koausa.org/vitasta/pdf/Vitasta1999-2000.pdf]</ref> However, the traditional Kashmiri suthan is loose, similar to the styles worn in [[Afghanistan]]<ref>Asoke Kumar Bhattacharyya, Pradip Kumar Sengupta Foundations of Indian Musicology: Perspectives in the Philosophy of Art and Culture (1991) [https://books.google.com/books?id=8EJw6O4VFFsC&pg=PA110&dq=ghagra+in+himachal+pradesh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=igRuVbfNO-n5ywPdsoOoCg&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=pheran&f=false]</ref> with some wearing styles similar to the Dogri suthan. The Punjabi salwar suit has also become popular.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=x510VZv8Ece0UfCIgeAL&id=PwM7AAAAMAAJ&dq=shalwar+kameez+kashmir&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=shalwar+kameez Dhar, Somnath (1986) Jammu and Kashmir folklore]</ref>
Elsewhere in [[India]] and [[Pakistan]], Muslim communities have traditionally worn the style of salwar worn by the [[Mughals]] combining them with [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] upper garments such as the jamma. However, the Punjabi salwar suit is now worn by members of various communities in India<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=iY4bVR9--XAC&pg=PA141&dq=punjab+kurta+history&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gph0VfTWNMPpUovugOgJ&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=punjab%20kurta%20history&f=false Subba, J.R (2008) History, Culture and Customs of Sikkim]</ref> and Pakistan.
The traditional male dress in Bangladesh is the lungi and kurta (also called Panjabi). Men also wear the Pathani suit. The traditional female dress is the sari but women also wear the Punjabi salwar suit.
The salwar is a traditional garment in [[Afghanistan]] worn by men as the [[Khet partug]] outfit. The Khet is the tunic, similar to a robe and the partoog is the Afghanistan salwar, with multiple pleats. The male dress also includes the [[perahan tunban]]. The Pathani suit <ref>{{cite web|title=Celebrating Indianness|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/fashion/designers/Celebrating-Indianness/articleshow/7792864.cms?referral=PM|work=.indiatimes.com|accessdate=27 March 2014|date=Mar 27, 2011}}</ref> has become popular since the 1990s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Perahan Tunban 'Mens clothes'|url=http://www.afghanistan-culture.com/perahan-tunban.html|work=afghanistan-culture.com|accessdate=27 March 2014}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=bY8ck6iktikC&pg=PA151&lpg=PA151&dq=afghan+sikh+culture&source=bl&ots=HZnJ_-ozKa&sig=5bNpi6TwiBI0HurXXg6IZs6xc8Y&hl=en&sa=X&ei=LnBqVNCeBsPLaK_XgOAB&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=afghan%20sikh%20culture&f=false Culture and Customs of Afghanistan By Hafizullah Emadi ]</ref> The female Punjabi suit is also popular in [[Afghanistan]] which is called the Panjabi.<ref>[http://missbspage.weebly.com/uploads/1/3/9/8/13980362/afghanistan_clothing.pdf Afghanistan clothing]</ref><ref>Pia Karlsson, Amir Mansory (2007) An Afghan dilemma: education, gender and globalisation in an Islamic context [https://books.google.com/books?id=RGElAQAAIAAJ&dq=afghan+and+punjabi+dress&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+punjabi+]</ref>

[[Warner Premiere]] | budget = | network = | picture_format = | audio_format = | released = September 23, 2008 }} '''''Scooby-Doo and the Goblin King''''' is a 2008 [[direct-to-DVD]] [[animation|animated]] [[comedy horror]] [[fantasy film]], and the twelfth in the series of ''[[Scooby-Doo]]'' direct-to-video films produced by [[Warner Bros. Animation]] (though it used a [[Hanna-Barbera]] logo at the end of the movie). It was dedicated to Paulette Oates, who helped resurrect Warner Bros. Animation in the late 1980s. All the main voice actors of Mystery, Inc. reprise their roles. The DVD was released on September 23, 2008. This is the first Scooby cartoon produced entirely without either one of the original creators, [[William Hanna]] and [[Joseph Barbera]]. Unlike the previous seven movies, this film is similar to ''[[Scooby-Doo on Zombie Island|Zombie Island]]'', ''[[Scooby-Doo! and the Witch's Ghost|Witch's Ghost]]'' (which previously featured [[Tim Curry]]), ''[[Scooby-Doo and the Alien Invaders|Alien Invaders]]'' and ''[[Scooby-Doo and the Cyber Chase|Cyber Chase]]'', by making all the fantastical elements of the story real. ==Plot== The Mystery, Inc. gang visit a [[Halloween]] [[carnival]] on Halloween night. When the [[Magic (illusion)|magician]] "The Amazing Krudsky" (voiced by [[Wayne Knight]]) refuses to allow Scooby to see his show, he and Shaggy retaliate by exposing Krudsky as a fraud during one of his acts, resulting in the magician swearing revenge, his audience walking out on him, and the gang getting thrown out of the carnival. The rebellious [[Fairy]] Princess Willow (voiced by [[Hayden Panettiere]]) later enters Krudsky's tent, where he secretly reveals his wishes to become a real magician. The fairy inadvertently causes Krudsky to notice her on the [[Goblin]] Scepter in a spell book, which can be combined with fairy magic to control Halloween. Krudsky then gets an idea to obtain the scepter and rule the world with it. Willow decides to toy with him, but while flying, she accidentally slams her small body against a metal chair knocking her out; Krudsky then crushes her with his [[flyswatter]]. When he notices her cry of pain from being crushed, he sees that she is a real fairy, kidnaps her, and absorbs her magical powers, thus becoming a real magician. Meanwhile, Scooby-Doo and the gang go [[trick-or-treating]] all night. Shaggy's and Scooby's last stop is a spooky looking house which claims to be a "genuine magic shoppe". However, a very loud thunderstorm also begins, frightening the heroes. Inside, they meet the kind proprietor of the magic shop Mr. Gibbles (voiced by [[Wallace Shawn]]), who reveals to the duo that magic really does exist. At that moment, Willow enters being chased by Krudsky; he captures her and turns Gibbles into a [[rabbit]], and steals the magic equipment before leaving. Mr. Gibbles explains to an astonished Shaggy and Scooby that Krudsky, after capturing the good magic of the princess, will now want the bad magic held in the scepter of the Goblin King, which will, as well, cause an imbalance in the supernatural order which will make Halloween remain forever and as a result will turn every human into horrifying monsters. Shaggy and Scooby board the Grim Reaper Railway which flies them to the spirit world. Once they arrive, the two realize that they need to get the scepter before Krudsky can, and return home before sunrise or else they will be trapped in the magic world forever. Before they depart, Gibbles gives them magic cards that perform spells just by reading the inscription on each one; however, the deck has to be saved for emergencies because each card can only be used once and each spell is temporary. To make it less suspicious-looking, Shaggy and Scooby are magically disguised by being transformed into monster-like versions of themselves. While looking for Shaggy and Scooby, Fred, Daphne and Velma see Krudsky conversing with the Goblin King through a mirror where the Goblin King (voiced by [[Tim Curry]]) reluctantly agrees to exchange his scepter for Princess Willow at midnight at a clock tower. However, seeing that all the evil magic and the Goblin King are real causes Velma's rational mind to shut down and Velma herself to fall unconscious; Fred and Daphne leave Velma to rest and go to the tower and set a trap for both the Goblin King and Krudsky. Back in the magic world, Shaggy and Scooby go to a bar owned by a [[werewolf]] (also voiced by [[Tim Curry]]). During the song "Bump in the Night", Shaggy adds in the lyric on how to get to the Goblin King's castle. Shaggy and Scooby-Doo find that everyone is afraid of the Goblin King and will not help them upon running off. The Goblin King's two bumbling goblin henchmen, Glob and Glum (voiced by [[James Belushi]] and [[Larry Joe Campbell]]), attempt to capture Scooby and Shaggy, but the latter two are saved and lead away by [[Jack-o'-lantern|Jack O'Lantern]] (voiced by [[Jay Leno]]), a living pumpkin who leads them to three [[Witchcraft|witches]] while running away from the [[Headless Horseman (Legend of Sleepy Hollow)|Headless Horseman]]. Along the way, they narrowly avoid the chasing monster (who was Jack's former body) by heading across a covered bridge which he cannot cross. The three of them arrive at the [[Witchcraft|Witches]]' Hut where they meet the Grand Witch (voiced by [[Lauren Bacall]]) and her two fellow witches (voiced by [[Grey DeLisle]] and [[Russi Taylor]]). The witches send Shaggy and Scooby on a ride on their flying broomstick nicknamed "Broomy" towards the Goblin King's castle, but they are shot down by Glob and Glum by a goblin gun-like cannon. Crash-landing in a small fairy village, Shaggy and Scooby find three fairies named Sparkplug, Honeybee and Tiddlywink, who help them to the Goblin King's castle entrance. Reluctantly using a potion from the witches (made from someone called "Scratch"), Shaggy and Scooby disguise themselves as Daphne (Shaggy) and Velma (Scooby) in order for Glob and Glum to let them into the castle. Only a few minutes away from midnight, Shaggy and Scooby try to run off with the scepter, but are captured and sent to the dungeon by the Goblin King who heads off to meet with Krudsky. At the clock tower, Krudsky and the Goblin King are almost through with their trade when Fred and Daphne release a trap and run off with the fairy princess. But the trap only catches the Goblin King and Krudsky takes the scepter, turning himself into the new Goblin King before turning the Goblin King into a [[goose]]. Krudsky and his new goblin army set off to take over the world. He turns the Mystery Machine into a living monster vehicle called the "Monstrous Machine" to chase Fred, Daphne, and the now-awakened Velma. The goblins capture the three and Krudsky uses his newfound powers to turn Fred into a [[vampire]], Daphne into a [[Witchcraft|witch]], and Velma into a [[werewolf]] (respectively). At that moment, however, Scooby, Shaggy and Jack O'Lantern arrive having been saved from the dungeon before sunrise by the fairies and Broomy. Jack apparently sacrifices himself to strip Krudsky of the staff of which Scooby uses to break Krudsky's spells, restoring his friends, the Mystery Machine, Mr. Gibbles, and the Goblin King back to normal where he reclaims his staff from Scooby-Doo and then uses his restored powers to imprison Krudsky. The Goblin King is revealed to be Willow's father who holds her responsible for all the trouble caused and grounds her for a year as punishment, though he does admits that he is relieved to have her back. Mr. Gibbles brings Jack back to life with the Goblin King's help, who then takes Krudsky prisoner for both his crimes and treachery (the Goblin King tells him that he will have plenty of time to "work on his act"). He, the goblin army, Willow, Jack, Broomy and Mr. Gibbles all leave and return to the magical world. But before departing and to also keep the balance between the worlds, the Goblin King uses one final spell to erase the memory of the events from Fred's, Daphne's, Velma's, and the others' minds. However, Scooby and Shaggy are allowed to keep theirs as they have proven their courage. As morning comes, Fred, Daphne and Velma forget what transpired (due to the effects of the memory-erasing spell) as Shaggy and Scooby-Doo come to pick them up. As the carnival packs up, Scooby uses an unpacked mirror one last time to spook the gang as the film ends. ==Original monsters== {{prose|date=February 2017}} Some monsters from ''[[Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!]]'', ''[[The New Scooby-Doo Movies]]'', ''[[The Scooby-Doo Show]]'', ''[[Scooby-Doo and Scrappy-Doo (1979 TV series)|Scooby-Doo and Scrappy-Doo]]'', ''[[What's New, Scooby-Doo?]]'' and ''[[Scooby-Doo! and the Legend of the Vampire]]'' are sighted in this movie: * The monsters that are seen during the "Bump in the Night" song include the [[Werewolf]] Ghost from "Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Werewolf", the Phantom Shadow from "A Night of Fright is No Delight", the Creeper from "Jeepers! It's the Creeper", the [[Mummy (monster)|Mummy]] of Ankha from "Scooby-Doo and a Mummy, Too", the Snow Ghost from "That's Snow Ghost," the Ghost of [[Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde (character)|Mr. Hyde]] from "Nowhere to Hyde", the No-Faced [[Zombie]] from "The No-Faced Zombie Chase Case", the Ozark [[Witchcraft|Witch]] from "The Ozark Witch Switch", [[Penguin (character)|Penguin]]'s [[Troll]] disguise from "The Caped Crusader Caper", a blue version of Roller Ghoster from "Roller Ghoster Ride", the Kelp Monster from "Scooby-Doo, Where's the Crew?", the Specter of Ebenezer Crabbe from "High Rise Hair Raiser", and the Ghost of the Great Haldane from "The Sorcerer's a Menace". * The [[Black knight|Black Knight]] from "What a Night for a Knight" briefly appears during Mr. Gibbles' song "Who's At the Door". ==Cast== * [[Frank Welker]] - [[Scooby-Doo (character)|Scooby-Doo]], [[Fred Jones (Scooby-Doo)|Fred Jones]] * [[Casey Kasem]] - [[Shaggy Rogers]] * [[Mindy Cohn]] - [[Velma Dinkley]] * [[Grey DeLisle]] - [[Daphne Blake]], Cat Witch, Honeybee * [[Wayne Knight]] - The Amazing Krudsky * [[Jay Leno]] - [[Jack-o'-lantern|Jack O'Lantern]] * [[Wallace Shawn]] - Mr. Gibbles * [[Tim Curry]] - The Goblin King, [[Werewolf]] Bar Owner * [[James Belushi]] - Glob * [[Larry Joe Campbell]] - Glum * [[Hayden Panettiere]] - Fairy Princess Willow * [[Lauren Bacall]] - The Grand Witch * [[Thom Adcox-Hernandez]] - Sparkplug * [[Russi Taylor]] - Owl Witch, Tiddlywink ==Original songs== {{prose|date=February 2017}} * "Who's At the Door" - Sung by [[Wallace Shawn]] * "Bump in the Night" - Sung by various Halloween Monsters * "Goblin Oogie Boogie" - Sung by [[James Belushi]] ==Follow-up film== * ''[[Scooby-Doo! {{Infobox book | name = Shiris ko Phool | author = [[Parijat (writer)|Parijat]] | language = [[Nepali language|Nepali]] | country = [[Nepal]] | genre = Novel | publisher = Sajha Prakashan, [[Kathmandu]], [[Nepal]] | isbn =9993340995 | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | title_orig =शिरीषको फूल | translator =Orchid Books | image = Shirish ko Phool.jpg | caption = Cover-page of Shiris ko Phool | illustrator = | cover_artist = | series =Shiris Ko Phool Book Series | pub_date =1965 | media_type = Print | pages =65 | dewey = | congress = | oclc = | preceded_by = | followed_by =The Blue Mimosa }} ==About Author== [[Parijat (writer)|Parijat]] was the nom de plume of Bishnu Kumari Waiba (1937-1993), a novelist, poet, and short story writer. Born in Darjeeling, India where she completed part of her schooling, she moved to Kathmandu, Nepal where she spent the rest of her life. Her first novel '''The Blue Mimosa.'''<ref>http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/10579671-blue-mimosa</ref> ({{lang-ne|शिरिषको फूल}}) was published in 1965. The novel received '''Madan Puraskar''', the award offered in Nepal for ''The Best Book Of The Year.'' She was, and still is regarded as the first modern novelist of Nepal. The novel is highly acclaimed in Nepali literature, proving to introduce Nepalese Literature in a global platform. It has been translated and adapted in the literature curriculum of some colleges in some English speaking countries.
==Summary==
Parijat is the pseudonym name claimed by Bishnu Kumari Waiba. In her book, Sirish ko Phool (Blue Mimosa), 1965, she writes through a male narrative. The flip of gender binaries strategically positions herself in the patriarchal environment during that time period and opens up a dialogue between the two.
The book enters a post war veteran sub context as the narrator that is engaged in various forms of communication of love and life and delves into the preconceived structures of gender binaries. It analyses and makes way for a critical dialogue about the complexities of identities and trauma. It highlights the irrelevance of a patriarchal community during a time of toxic patriarchy.
==Plot== ''Suyogbir,45,'' is the main male protagonist. An ex-army serviceman Suyog fought against Japan in the second world war but being poor hearted was not even able to kill a single soldier and had not received any medal. Although his village is in hills, he lives in Kathmandu valley. His daily routine has become to drink alcohol in the evenings in the bar. He brutally raped and murdered several indigenous girls and he remembers several incidents during the war.
He meets and becomes friend with ''Shivaraj'' in the bar. Shivaraj has three sisters: Mujura, Sakambari and Sanu. Suyogbir unknowingly becomes near to them all and falls in love with Sakambari but he finds difficult to tell her. One day finding her alone, he kisses her revealing his love towards her.
Later, ''Suyogbir'' stops visiting ''Shivaraj'' and his family. He later knows Sakambari was ill and one day he comes to know ''Sakambari'' has committed suicide.
Suyog concludes even one sided love kills.
== Translated Version == This book has been translated as Blue Mimosa by Orchid Books and it was published in 2010

[[Image:skullion.jpg|thumb|right|<center>[[David Jason]] as 'Skullion' in ''[[Porterhouse Blue#TV mini-series|Porterhouse Blue]]''</center>]]
'''Skullion''' is a central character in ''[[Porterhouse Blue]]'' (1974) and ''[[Grantchester Grind]]'' (1995), two novels about life in the fictitious [[Porterhouse College, Cambridge|Porterhouse College]] at [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] by [[United Kingdom|British]] novelist [[Tom Sharpe]]. For centuries, Porterhouse College has been renowned for its cuisine, the prowess of its rowers and the low level of its academic achievements. Since the College was founded there have been Skullions at Porterhouse.
Skullion is the Head [[Porter (college)|Porter]] at the College, a responsibility he has held for many years and which he takes very seriously indeed.
==Head Porter of Porterhouse College==
[[Image:Porterhouse Blue Book.jpg|thumb|right|175px|<center>Cover of 'Porterhouse Blue'</center>]] James Skullion's first contact with Porterhouse College came when, as a young boy, he carried the students' cases for sixpence when they arrived at the railway station at Cambridge, running beside their cabs to help unload them at the College. He became a Porter at Porterhouse in 1937 and served in the [[Royal Marines]] during the [[Second World War]]. He became the Head Porter in 1949. In the books, Skullion has worked at the College for forty-five years, has served seven Masters, and sees himself as a link with the College's great and glorious past; as such he regards it as his duty to maintain the standards of bygone years. Porterhouse is not an academic college; rather, it is a club for gentlemen, where admission depends on rank and wealth and where degrees can be bought. This often involves a brighter substitute from another college being paid to take the place of the Porterhouse student in the examination. Based on their fraudulent degrees, many of these students have gone on to obtain positions of great power in government and industry. These men are known as '' 'Skullion's Scholars' ''. He keeps their names on a list, knowing it will be useful one day.
When the Master of Porterhouse dies without naming his successor, the College Visitor, the Queen, takes the [[Prime Minister|Prime Minister's]] advice and appoints [[Sir Godber Evans]] (a former student at the College) as his successor. Sir Godber, having been pressured by his wealthy [[left-wing]] wife, Lady Mary, announces sweeping changes to the centuries of College tradition, much to the concern of Skullion and the [[Fellow]]s, who plan a [[counter attack]] to the proposed [[Condom machine|contraceptive machines]], women students, and a self-service canteen. He also intends to sell the row of houses where the College servants live.
Skullion contemptuously remembers Sir Godber from his student days as not being a gentleman as he had been educated at a [[grammar school]]. Skullion is sacked for insolence by Sir Godber, the new Master, and is forced to leave his home. He appears live on a television programme in which he reveals all of the College's murky secrets, and refers to his list of '' 'Skullion's Scholars' '', to the horror of Sir Godber and the College's Senior Fellows, but to the amusement of everybody else.
Skullion returns to Cambridge, determined to ask for his job back in return for donating a large inheritance he has received to the College. He confronts Sir Godber who treats him with pity and contempt. This angers Skullion's sense of pride, and he advances menacingly on Sir Godber, who, backing away in fear, trips and bangs his head. He is found dying by the Dean and Senior Tutor and tries to tell them who is responsible. They misunderstand his meaning and believe that he has named Skullion as his successor as Master. They inform Skullion of this and he suffers a '' 'Porterhouse Blue' '', a [[stroke]], but survives and is installed as Master of the College.
==Master of Porterhouse== [[Image:grantchestergrind.jpg|thumb|right|175px|<center>Cover of ''Grantchester Grind''</center>]] In ''[[Grantchester Grind]]'' the wheel-chair bound Skullion is still Master, but is showing signs of physical frailty. The mystery surrounding the death of the previous Master, Sir Godber Evans, prompts his widow, the millionairess Lady Mary, to instigate a plan to investigate the death through a planted Fellow, Dr Purefoy Osbert, backed by a large, anonymous donation to Porterhouse.
At the same time, the Dean decides to look for a new Master for the College, preferably a wealthy one, to replace Skullion; he drives around the country visiting Old Porterthusians (previous students at Porterhouse), including [[Lord Jeremy Pimpole]], (who is now a chronic alcoholic with a sexual predilection for sheep and dogs), in the hope that he will find one is willing to become Master. None is suitable. Meanwhile, the College Bursar is contacted by the American media and drug-running [[billionaire]] Edgar Hartang, who seems to be interested in supporting the College without clarifying what it is he wants in return. Knowing that Dr Osbert is eavesdropping, Skullion admits that he murdered Sir Godber Evans. He is immediately and secretly sent to ''Porterhouse Park'', an unpleasant retirement home for the College's mad or troublesome Fellows. He escapes from here with the assistance of Dr Osbert, and returns to Porterhouse and confronts the Fellows. As is his right as Master, Skullion nominates the new Master of the College, the alcoholic Lord Pimpole.
==Skullion in film== In 1987 ''[[Porterhouse Blue]]'' was adapted for television as ''[[Porterhouse Blue (TV series)|Porterhouse Blue]]'' by [[Malcolm Bradbury]] for [[Channel 4]], with [[David Jason]] playing the role of Skullion,<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092428/ ''Porterhouse Blue'' on the [[Internet Movie Database]]]</ref> and winning a [[BAFTA]] for Best Actor for the role.

Untalan |lyrics_date = |composer = Ramon Manalisay Sablan |music_date = |adopted = 1919 |until = |sound = |sound_title = }} '''Stand Ye Guamanians''' ({{lang-ch|Fanohge Chamoru}}), generically known as '''The Guam Hymn''', is the official territorial anthem of [[Guam]]. ==History and usage== Adopted in 1919, the words and music were written in English by Dr. Ramon Manalisay Sablan. The Chamorro translation was the work of [[Lagrimas L.G. Untalan]], and it is this later version that enjoys wider usage today. As a [[United States dependency]], the official [[national anthem]] is still the "[[Star Spangled Banner]]", which is always played before the Guam Hymn on official occasions. The Guam Hymn, however, is played alone at international sports competitions. ==Lyrics== === Chamorro === :{{lang|ch|Fanohge Chamoru put i tano'-ta :Kånta i ma tunå-ña gi todu i lugåt. :Para i onra, para i gloria :Abiba i isla sen parat. :Para i onra, para i gloria :Abiba i isla sen parat. :U todu i tiempo i pas para hita :Yan ginen i langet na bendesion. :Kontra i piligru, na'fansåfo' ham :Yu'os prutehi i islan Guåhan. :Kontra i piligru, na'fansåfo' ham :Yu'os prutehi i islan Guåhan.}} === English === :Stand ye Guamanians for your country :And sing her praise from shore to shore :For her honor, for her glory :Exalt our isle forever more. :For her honor, for her glory :Exalt our isle forever more. :May everlasting peace reign o'er us :May Heaven's blessing to us come :Against all peril, do not forsake us :God protect our isle of Guam. :Against all peril, do not forsake us :God protect our isle of Guam. == External links == * [http://guampedia.com/guam-hymn-fanohge-chamorro/ Guampedia, Guam's Online Encyclopedia Guam Hymn] * [http://music.stream.national-anthems.net/?from=real&what=guam&id=GQ Real Audio file (instrumental)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://ns.gov.gu/fanoghe/ The Guam Hymn, Government of Guam] {{National Anthems of Oceania and the Pacific Islands}} [[Category:Guamanian culture]] [[Category:Anthems of insular areas of the United States]] [[Category:Oceanian anthems]] {{Guam-stub}} {{anthem-stub}}
